description:
Following extensive road work at the intersection of Williams Street and Washington Street this summer (entire month of August and most of July), the integrity of the road has been compromised resulting in our residence at 10 Williams street shaking frighteningly and a loud booming noise every time a truck, bus, or other vehicle drives through the intersection. We are just 2 blocks from Dudley Square and on a very busy street, so the noise and shaking continue 24 hours a day.

It sounds and feels as though these vehicles are driving over a large hole in the ground that is covered by a thin plate or covering of some sort. The shaking and thunderous noise occurs when a vehicle drives over the dark square seen in the center of the photo (between the two spray painted lines). Something is not sitting right in that area and is causing noise and significant vibrations.

I am deeply concerned that the extensive digging into the ground has loosened the supporting soil around our building, thereby compromising its structural integrity. The entire building shakes now following the construction, it did not before.

Someone needs to inspect the street in the areas where the construction was done and ensure that our building is not in danger of collapsing on itself because of it.

Hi! Lucky's Lounge frequently leaves the door open while bands are playing — it's the door farthest from the corner of A Street (i.e. the door right next to the band). I've asked them politely (in person during the day) not to; I've tried calling while it's happening at night but they don't pick up; I've called the non-emergency police line, which stops it that night but then it happens again the next night. They don't seem to care about the city noise ordinance or their neighbors. I don't expect silence from a bar by any means—I understand what city living entails. But I don't think it's unreasonable to expect to not hear a very loud snare drum after 11pm on a Sunday when the solution is as simple as shutting the door. Can anything be done to stop this silliness? Thank you!

Hello. 

I have a neighbor that is feeding a skunk and 2 raccoons. I have seen him leave meals in bowls on his back porch for these animals. 

I believe the skunk is living under his shed and the raccoons appear to live in the tree on his property. I have 2 children and 2 dogs and while I don't want to be confrontational, I would like to ask him to stop and I want to be able to properly inform him if this practice of feeding wild mammals is not allowed in the city of Boston. They are, in a sense, becoming his pets. 

If there is a specific ordinance could you please send me a link to it so I can share the details with him. 

Thank you.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following: National Grid activated a Grade 1 emergency repair on September 13th. They rectified the Grade 1 emergency repair but still needed to continue working to make the full repair. They converted to a normal excavation permit on September 15th. The work hours for that permit are 7-am4pm. They should not be working after 4:00 unless another emergency has taken place. I have reached out to National Grid Rep Peter Nagle to reach out to you and address each one of your concerns. Peter's email address is peter.nagle@nationalgrid.com. We apologize for the inconvenience. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description: When is the construction going to be done on E 7th and Viking???? The fact that the work is not starting until around 4PM and is going past 8PM at night seems illogical. There is so much noise, and there is NO PARKING for blocks due to signs that are saving spots for the vehicles ALL DAY that don't arrive until the evening. This is absolutely ridiculous and has been going on for weeks now!
address: Intersection Of Viking St & E Seventh St, South Boston

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector spoke to the contractor and reminded him that he needs to strictly follow the city's dust control protocols when excavating in the city. You should see an immediate improvement. The CIU inspector will regularly monitor this location to ensure full compliance. National Grid is replacing a gas main that is almost 100 years old.  The city encourages this type of capital upgrade work.  It will provide dependable gas service to the residents as well as eliminate future emergency repairs. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the placement of a new gas main is well worth it. National Grid has to install the gas main first.  Once the main has been installed, then all service connections can be made. If the City were to make National Grid pave to grade each day's trench work,  it would cause multiple seams along the trench. More importantly, every service connection needs to be cut into the trench.  If we were to pave the trench every day,  this would result in 2 by 2 patches inside the trench area, ending up with a very poor final paved product. In order to have the best final paving, the City allows the utility company to leave the trench down low until all service connections are made and then pave the trench all at once, resulting in a smooth, level final trench repair. Service laterals are topped within 24 hours of excavation. What the constituent is observing is the trench left down low in preparation for one continuous final paving operation. We do require that the contractor place florescent orange signs ahead of the construction informing motorists that the trench ahead is down low. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. National Grid is replacing a gas main that is over 100 years old. In addition to replacing a 100 year old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident/business. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However replacing mains over 100 years old ensures solid dependable gas service for another 100 years. In speaking with the National Grid Supervisor he states  the paving crew showed up late that night to top the trench.. Feeney Brothers has spoken with the crew and this will not happen again. The good news is that National Grid states this work will be completed this week. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. When the City paves or reconstructed a street it wants a 5 year moratorium on any excavation work. We call these streets guaranteed streets. In order to have  the most efficient coordination for streets not to be dug up after paving has taken place the Boston Public Works Construction Management Division (CMD) created an online reservation system for all utility and road and sidewalk work. The reservation system is called the City of Boston Utility Coordination Software (COBUCS). No one can get a permit without entering the job into the COBUCS system. Since COBUCS has been developed in 2010 there have been over 10,000 conflicts identified where paving was held up until the work was done. . If COBUCS didn?t flag those conflicts it would have cost utility companies, private homeowners/business, rate payers, and City Departments over $35 Million Dollars in paving restoration fees on guaranteed streets. We still may end up with guaranteed street cuts due to emergency work or development after the coordination process and paving is completed. We consider COBUCS a rousing success and Boston is glad that we have the system. When it comes to Peter Parley and the other streets in Jamaica Plain, we coordinated with Verizon to make sure that any work for the Fios system that needed to be done, was done before paving took place. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.

description: We need a parent pick-up/drop-off sign in front of Up Academy Dorchester. Every morning a meter maid comes down Westville street and tickets parents that are dropping off their children at school at Up Academy Dorchester. Every. Single. Morning. It's like we are being punished for being good parents and walking our children into school. They literally have to be waiting around for us to leave our cars. Trust me, no one is  parking their car in a no parking zone - we are dropping our children off (long after the school buses arrive to drop off those who take the bus) leaving our cars idling in front of the school for less than five minutes. Today, in less than the three minutes it took to walk my child to his classroom, I returned to my car and had a ticket placed for the minute I left my car, meaning the meter maid literally watched me take my child out the car and walk into the school but still gave a number of us tickets. There is literally no where else to park in the very cdensky settled area, between resident and employee parking, we are not left with many options for parking when dropping off our children. City of Boston, you should be ashamed. This is wrong.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. National Grid is replacing a gas main that is over 100 years old. In addition to replacing a 100 year old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident/business. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However replacing mains over 100 years old ensures solid dependable gas service for another 100 years. National Grid is required to send letters to each of the residents before the construction starts informing them of the job and contact information. The National Grid Public Relations Rep Peter Nagle can be contacted at 617-293-1490 regarding your claim that you were not notified. Peter can also give you a good esitmated time of completion on when the new gas main will be completed. .  The CIU Inspector for your neighborhood is Mal Flynn.  Mall can be rached at 781-983-4201. You can call Mal anytime regarding issues on the street that need immediate attention. Again the City apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. In the Summer we were notified a contractor was digging on Everdean St doing service work. It was determined that this contractor did not have a Public Works permit, and was ordered to stop work immediately. We told him he needed to be bonded first in order to receive a permit. status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. National Grid is replacing the  gas main on Downer Ave  that is over 100 years old. In addition to replacing a 100 year old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident/business. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However replacing mains over 100 years old ensures solid dependable gas service for another 100 years. National Grid is required to send letters to each of the residents before the construction starts informing them of the job and contact information. The National Grid Public Relations Rep Peter Nagle can be contacted at 617-293-1490.  The CIU Inspector for your neighborhood is Mal Flynn at 781-983-4201. You can call Mal anytime regarding issues on the street that need immediate attention. Again the City apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
